segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was so large a house, that she did not like to go nearer till she had nibbled some more of the lefthand bit of mushroom, and raised herself to about two feet high: even then she walked up towards it rather timidly, saying to herself “Suppose it should be raving mad after all! I almost wish I’d gone to see the Hatter instead!”

events.text_segment:
Alice didn’t think that proved it at all; however, she went on “And how do you know that you’re mad?”
“To begin with,” said the Cat, “a dog’s not mad. You grant that?”
“I suppose so,” said Alice.
“Well, then,” the Cat went on, “you see, a dog growls when it’s angry, and wags its tail when it’s pleased. Now I growl when I’m pleased, and wag my tail when I’m angry. Therefore I’m mad.”
“I call it purring, not growling,” said Alice.
“Call it what you like,” said the Cat. “Do you play croquet with the Queen to-day?”
“I should like it very much,” said Alice, “but I haven’t been invited yet.”
“You’ll see me there,” said the Cat, and vanished.
Alice was not much surprised at this, she was getting so used to queer things happening. While she was looking at the place where it had been, it suddenly appeared again.
“By-the-bye, what became of the baby?” said the Cat. “I’d nearly forgotten to ask.”
“It turned into a pig,” Alice quietly said, just as if it had come back in a natural way.
“I thought it would,” said the Cat, and vanished again.
Alice waited a little, half expecting to see it again, but it did not appear, and after a minute or two she walked on in the direction in which the March Hare was said to live. “I’ve seen hatters before,” she said to herself; “the March Hare will be much the most interesting, and perhaps as this is May it won’t be raving mad—at least not so mad as it was in March.” As she said this, she looked up, and there was the Cat again, sitting on a branch of a tree.
“Did you say pig, or fig?” said the Cat.
“I said pig,” replied Alice; “and I wish you wouldn’t keep appearing and vanishing so suddenly: you make one quite giddy.”
“All right,” said the Cat; and this time it vanished quite slowly, beginning with the end of the tail, and ending with the grin, which remained some time after the rest of it had gone.
“Well! I’ve often seen a cat without a grin,” thought Alice; “but a grin without a cat! It’s the most curious thing I ever saw in my life!”
She had not gone much farther before she came in sight of the house of the March Hare: she thought it must be the right house, because the chimneys were shaped like ears and the roof was thatched with fur. It was so large a house, that she did not like to go nearer till she had nibbled some more of the lefthand bit of mushroom, and raised herself to about two feet high: even then she walked up towards it rather timidly, saying to herself “Suppose it should be raving mad after all! I almost wish I’d gone to see the Hatter instead!”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Alice wasn't convinced by his explanation, yet she pressed on, asking, "And how are you certain that you're insane?" The Cat replied, "For starters, a dog isn't insane. You agree with that, don't you?" Alice conceded, "I suppose so." "Very well," the Cat continued, "you see, a dog snarls when it's upset and wags its tail when it's pleased. Now, I snarl when I'm pleased, and I wag my tail when I'm upset. Therefore, I am insane." Alice countered, "I'd call that purring, not snarling." The Cat dismissed this, saying, "Call it whatever you wish. Are you playing croquet with the Queen today?" Alice responded, "I'd love to, but I haven't received an invitation yet." "You'll find me there," the Cat stated before disappearing. Alice wasn't particularly surprised, as she was becoming accustomed to strange occurrences. As she stared at the spot where the Cat had been, it suddenly materialized again. "Incidentally, what became of the infant?" the Cat inquired. "I nearly forgot to ask." Alice calmly replied, "It transformed into a swine," speaking as if such a thing were entirely normal. "I suspected it might," said the Cat, and vanished once more. Alice lingered for a while, half expecting to see it reappear, but it didn't. After a minute or two, she proceeded in the direction where the March Hare was said to reside. She mused to herself, "I've encountered hat makers before; the March Hare will likely be far more fascinating, and perhaps since it's May, he won't be raving lunatic—at least, not as lunatic as he was in March." As she thought this, she glanced up and saw the Cat perched on a tree branch, back again. "Did you utter 'pig' or 'fig'?" the Cat asked. "I said 'pig'," Alice reiterated, "and I wish you would stop appearing and disappearing so abruptly; it makes one quite dizzy." "Understood," the Cat replied, and this time it faded away quite gradually, starting with the tip of its tail and finishing with its grin, which lingered for some time after the rest of its body was gone. "Remarkable! I've frequently seen a feline without a smirk," Alice thought, "but a smirk without a feline! It's the oddest thing I've ever witnessed in my entire life!" She hadn't gone much further before she spotted the March Hare's dwelling. She was certain it was the correct place because the chimneys resembled ears and the roof was covered with animal fur. The house was so large that she hesitated to approach until she had taken another bite of the piece of mushroom from her left hand side, raising herself to a height of about two feet. Even then, she cautiously walked towards it, telling herself, "What if he turns out to be completely mad after all! I almost regret not going to visit the Hatter instead!"

Alice didn’t think that was convincing proof, but she continued, "How can you tell if you’re mad?" 

The Cat responded, "First of all, dogs aren’t mad. You agree, right?"

"I think so," Alice answered.

"Well," the Cat said, "dogs growl when they're angry and wag their tails when they're happy. I, on the other hand, growl when I’m pleased and wag my tail when I’m angry. So, I must be mad."

"I would call it purring, not growling," Alice remarked.

"Call it whatever you like," replied the Cat. "Are you playing croquet with the Queen today?"

"I’d love to, but I haven’t been invited yet," Alice replied.

"You’ll see me there," said the Cat, before disappearing.

Alice wasn’t too surprised, as she was becoming accustomed to strange things happening. As she gazed at the spot where the Cat had been, it suddenly reappeared.

"By the way, what happened to the baby?" the Cat asked. "I almost forgot to ask."

"It became a pig," Alice said calmly, as if this was nothing unusual.

"I thought that’s what would happen," said the Cat, vanishing again.

Alice waited a bit, half expecting the Cat to return, but it didn’t. After a minute or two, she headed towards the place where the March Hare supposedly lived. "I’ve seen hatters before," she thought, "the March Hare should be more interesting. And since it’s May, maybe he won’t be as mad now as he was in March." Just as she thought this, she looked up and saw the Cat again on a tree branch.

"Pig," said Alice. "And I wish you wouldn’t keep appearing and disappearing so abruptly—it makes me dizzy."

"Alright," said the Cat, and this time it disappeared slowly, starting from the tip of its tail and ending with its grin, which lingered after the rest had gone.

"Well! I’ve seen cats without grins before," Alice thought, "but never a grin without a cat. That’s the strangest thing I’ve ever seen!"

The house was so big that she hesitated to approach it until she nibbled some more of the mushroom to grow to about two feet tall. Even then, she walked towards it rather cautiously, saying to herself, "What if he’s still completely mad? I almost wish I’d gone to see the Hatter instead!"

events.title: Alice Joins the Mad Tea-Party and Encounters Illogical Banter
detailed_summary: Alice discovers the March Hare, Hatter, and a sleeping Dormouse having tea, with the Dormouse being used as an elbow-rest.
Despite the large table, the trio claims there is no room when Alice approaches.
Alice asserts there's plenty of space and seats herself in an armchair.
The March Hare offers non-existent wine, leading to a brief argument about civility.
The Hatter makes a personal remark about Alice's hair, which she rebukes as rude.
The Hatter ignores her reprimand and poses the riddle, "Why is a raven like a writing-desk?".
Alice expresses interest in guessing the riddle.
A semantic argument ensues, initiated by the March Hare, about the difference between saying what one means and meaning what one says.
The Hatter and March Hare provide examples illustrating the difference (e.g., 'see what I eat' vs. 'eat what I see').
The Dormouse interjects with a similar comparison related to breathing and sleeping.
The Hatter dismisses the Dormouse's point as irrelevant to its state, and the conversation pauses as Alice ponders the riddle.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting between them, fast asleep, and the other two were using it as a cushion, resting their elbows on it, and talking over its head.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It is the same thing with you,” said the Hatter, and here the conversation dropped, and the party sat silent for a minute, while Alice thought over all she could remember about ravens and writing-desks, which wasn’t much.

events.text_segment:
There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting between them, fast asleep, and the other two were using it as a cushion, resting their elbows on it, and talking over its head. “Very uncomfortable for the Dormouse,” thought Alice; “only, as it’s asleep, I suppose it doesn’t mind.”
The table was a large one, but the three were all crowded together at one corner of it: “No room! No room!” they cried out when they saw Alice coming. “There’s plenty of room!” said Alice indignantly, and she sat down in a large arm-chair at one end of the table.
“Have some wine,” the March Hare said in an encouraging tone.
Alice looked all round the table, but there was nothing on it but tea. “I don’t see any wine,” she remarked.
“There isn’t any,” said the March Hare.
“Then it wasn’t very civil of you to offer it,” said Alice angrily.
“It wasn’t very civil of you to sit down without being invited,” said the March Hare.
“I didn’t know it was your table,” said Alice; “it’s laid for a great many more than three.”
“Your hair wants cutting,” said the Hatter. He had been looking at Alice for some time with great curiosity, and this was his first speech.
“You should learn not to make personal remarks,” Alice said with some severity; “it’s very rude.”
The Hatter opened his eyes very wide on hearing this; but all he said was, “Why is a raven like a writing-desk?”
“Come, we shall have some fun now!” thought Alice. “I’m glad they’ve begun asking riddles.—I believe I can guess that,” she added aloud.
“Do you mean that you think you can find out the answer to it?” said the March Hare.
“Exactly so,” said Alice.
“Then you should say what you mean,” the March Hare went on.
“I do,” Alice hastily replied; “at least—at least I mean what I say—that’s the same thing, you know.”
“Not the same thing a bit!” said the Hatter. “You might just as well say that ‘I see what I eat’ is the same thing as ‘I eat what I see’!”
“You might just as well say,” added the March Hare, “that ‘I like what I get’ is the same thing as ‘I get what I like’!”
“You might just as well say,” added the Dormouse, who seemed to be talking in his sleep, “that ‘I breathe when I sleep’ is the same thing as ‘I sleep when I breathe’!”
“It is the same thing with you,” said the Hatter, and here the conversation dropped, and the party sat silent for a minute, while Alice thought over all she could remember about ravens and writing-desks, which wasn’t much.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Under a tree in front of the house, a tea table had been arranged. The March Hare and the Hatter were seated at it, having tea. Between them sat a Dormouse, fast asleep, whom the other two were using like a cushion, resting their elbows on it and talking over its head. Alice thought, "How uncomfortable for the Dormouse," adding, "but since it's asleep, I suppose it won't mind." Although the table was large, the three of them were huddled together closely at one corner. Spotting Alice approaching, they yelled, "No room! No room!" Alice retorted indignantly, "There is plenty of room!" and took a seat in a large armchair at the far end of the table. The March Hare, in a seemingly friendly tone, suggested, "Have some wine." Alice looked around the table but saw only tea. "I don't see any wine," she observed. The March Hare replied, "There isn't any." Annoyed, Alice stated, "Then it was very impolite of you to offer it." The March Hare countered, "It was very impolite of you to sit down without an invitation." Alice replied, "I didn't realize it was your table; it's set for many more than three." The Hatter, who had been studying Alice with intense curiosity, spoke for the first time, remarking, "Your hair needs cutting." Alice responded with considerable sternness, "You ought to learn not to make personal comments; it's very rude." Hearing this, the Hatter's eyes widened significantly, but his only response was, "Why is a raven like a writing-desk?" Alice, thinking, "Ah, this will be entertaining! I'm glad they're starting with riddles. I believe I can solve that," she said aloud. The March Hare asked, "Do you mean you think you can discover the answer?" "Precisely," Alice affirmed. "Then you should state exactly what you mean," the March Hare continued. "I do," Alice quickly replied, "at least—at least I mean what I say—that's the same thing, you know." "Absolutely not the same thing!" declared the Hatter. "You could just as easily claim that 'I see what I eat' is identical to 'I eat what I see'!" "You could just as easily claim," the March Hare added, "that 'I like what I get' is identical to 'I get what I like'!" "You could just as easily claim," mumbled the Dormouse, seemingly talking in his sleep, "that 'I breathe when I sleep' is identical to 'I sleep when I breathe'!" "With you, it is the same thing," the Hatter said, and the discussion ceased. The group remained silent for a moment while Alice pondered everything she could recall about ravens and writing-desks, which wasn't much.

events.title: The Hatter's Peculiar Watch and Discussion of Time
detailed_summary: The Hatter breaks the silence, asking Alice for the date while fiddling with his pocket watch.
Alice replies that it's the fourth.
The Hatter laments that his watch is two days incorrect and blames the March Hare for using butter, supposedly unsuitable for watch mechanisms.
The March Hare defends the quality of the butter.
The Hatter complains that crumbs must have entered because the March Hare used a bread-knife.
The March Hare examines the watch glumly, dips it in his tea, and reiterates that it was the best butter.
Alice observes the watch, noting its oddity: it shows the day of the month but not the time.
The Hatter questions why it should tell the time, comparing it to Alice's watch not telling the year.
Alice explains her watch doesn't need to show the year because the year remains constant for a long time.
The Hatter claims this is precisely the situation with his watch (implying time is static for him).

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Hatter was the first to break the silence.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Which is just the case with mine,” said the Hatter.

events.text_segment:
The Hatter was the first to break the silence. “What day of the month is it?” he said, turning to Alice: he had taken his watch out of his pocket, and was looking at it uneasily, shaking it every now and then, and holding it to his ear.
Alice considered a little, and then said “The fourth.”
“Two days wrong!” sighed the Hatter. “I told you butter wouldn’t suit the works!” he added looking angrily at the March Hare.
“It was the best butter,” the March Hare meekly replied.
“Yes, but some crumbs must have got in as well,” the Hatter grumbled: “you shouldn’t have put it in with the bread-knife.”
The March Hare took the watch and looked at it gloomily: then he dipped it into his cup of tea, and looked at it again: but he could think of nothing better to say than his first remark, “It was the best butter, you know.”
Alice had been looking over his shoulder with some curiosity. “What a funny watch!” she remarked. “It tells the day of the month, and doesn’t tell what o’clock it is!”
“Why should it?” muttered the Hatter. “Does your watch tell you what year it is?”
“Of course not,” Alice replied very readily: “but that’s because it stays the same year for such a long time together.”
“Which is just the case with mine,” said the Hatter.

Turning to the March Hare with annoyance, he declared, "I warned you the butter wouldn't work in the gears!" The March Hare answered softly, "It was the *best* butter." "Yes, but some crumbs must have gotten in as well," the Hatter complained. "You shouldn't have used a bread-knife to put it there." The March Hare took the watch and looked at it sadly; then he dipped it into his cup of tea and looked again, but could think of nothing better to say than his first comment: "It was the *best* butter, you know." "Certainly not," Alice responded promptly, "but that's because the year stays the same for such a long duration." "Which is precisely the situation with *mine*," the Hatter stated.

events.title: The Unanswerable Riddle and the Hatter's Quarrel with Time
detailed_summary: Alice is confused by the Hatter's nonsensical reasoning about his watch.
She politely admits she doesn't understand.
The Hatter abruptly changes the subject, pointing out the Dormouse is asleep again and pours tea on its nose.
The Dormouse wakes momentarily, agreeing with a remark it hadn't heard.
The Hatter asks Alice if she has solved the riddle.
Alice gives up and asks for the answer.
Both the Hatter and the March Hare admit they don't know the answer.
Alice expresses frustration, suggesting their time could be better spent than on unanswerable riddles.
The Hatter personifies Time as 'him', claiming Alice doesn't know Time and has likely never spoken to 'him'.
Alice mentions 'beating time' in music.
The Hatter explains Time doesn't like being beaten and describes how being on good terms with Time allows one to manipulate the clock, making it jump to meal times instantly.
Alice finds the idea appealing but questions if she'd be hungry.
The Hatter suggests one could keep it at mealtime indefinitely.
Alice asks if this is how the Hatter manages time.
The Hatter mournfully recounts his quarrel with Time during a concert where he sang a parody of 'Twinkle, twinkle, little star'.
The Dormouse briefly sings 'Twinkle, twinkle' in its sleep until pinched.
The Hatter continues, explaining the Queen of Hearts accused him of 'murdering the time' and ordered his execution.
He concludes that since his falling out with Time, it remains perpetually six o'clock.

Alice deduces they must keep moving around the table.

events.text_segment:
Alice felt dreadfully puzzled. The Hatter’s remark seemed to have no sort of meaning in it, and yet it was certainly English. “I don’t quite understand you,” she said, as politely as she could.
“The Dormouse is asleep again,” said the Hatter, and he poured a little hot tea upon its nose.
The Dormouse shook its head impatiently, and said, without opening its eyes, “Of course, of course; just what I was going to remark myself.”
“Have you guessed the riddle yet?” the Hatter said, turning to Alice again.
“No, I give it up,” Alice replied: “what’s the answer?”
“I haven’t the slightest idea,” said the Hatter.
“Nor I,” said the March Hare.
Alice sighed wearily. “I think you might do something better with the time,” she said, “than waste it in asking riddles that have no answers.”
“If you knew Time as well as I do,” said the Hatter, “you wouldn’t talk about wasting it. It’s him.”
“I don’t know what you mean,” said Alice.
“Of course you don’t!” the Hatter said, tossing his head contemptuously. “I dare say you never even spoke to Time!”
“Perhaps not,” Alice cautiously replied: “but I know I have to beat time when I learn music.”
“Ah! that accounts for it,” said the Hatter. “He won’t stand beating. Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he’d do almost anything you liked with the clock. For instance, suppose it were nine o’clock in the morning, just time to begin lessons: you’d only have to whisper a hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling! Half-past one, time for dinner!”
(“I only wish it was,” the March Hare said to itself in a whisper.)
“That would be grand, certainly,” said Alice thoughtfully: “but then—I shouldn’t be hungry for it, you know.”
“Not at first, perhaps,” said the Hatter: “but you could keep it to half-past one as long as you liked.”
“Is that the way you manage?” Alice asked.
The Hatter shook his head mournfully. “Not I!” he replied. “We quarrelled last March—just before he went mad, you know—” (pointing with his tea spoon at the March Hare,) “—it was at the great concert given by the Queen of Hearts, and I had to sing
‘Twinkle, twinkle, little bat!
How I wonder what you’re at!’
You know the song, perhaps?”
“I’ve heard something like it,” said Alice.
“It goes on, you know,” the Hatter continued, “in this way:—
‘Up above the world you fly,
Like a tea-tray in the sky.
                    Twinkle, twinkle—’”
Here the Dormouse shook itself, and began singing in its sleep “Twinkle, twinkle, twinkle, twinkle—” and went on so long that they had to pinch it to make it stop.
“Well, I’d hardly finished the first verse,” said the Hatter, “when the Queen jumped up and bawled out, ‘He’s murdering the time! Off with his head!’”
“How dreadfully savage!” exclaimed Alice.
“And ever since that,” the Hatter went on in a mournful tone, “he won’t do a thing I ask! It’s always six o’clock now.”
A bright idea came into Alice’s head. “Is that the reason so many tea-things are put out here?” she asked.
“Yes, that’s it,” said the Hatter with a sigh: “it’s always tea-time, and we’ve no time to wash the things between whiles.”
“Then you keep moving round, I suppose?” said Alice.
“Exactly so,” said the Hatter: “as the things get used up.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Alice felt extremely bewildered. The Hatter's comment made no sense to her, yet it was spoken in English. She responded, as politely as possible, "I don't quite follow you." The Hatter noted the Dormouse was asleep again and poured a little hot tea onto its nose. The Dormouse impatiently shook its head and, without opening its eyes, mumbled, "Obviously, obviously; precisely what I was about to say myself." Turning back to Alice, the Hatter asked, "Have you figured out the riddle yet?" "No, I give up," Alice replied. "What's the answer?" "I haven't the faintest notion," the Hatter stated. "Me neither," added the March Hare. Alice let out a tired sigh. "I believe you could use your time more productively," she commented, "instead of wasting it on riddles that have no solutions." "If your understanding of Time was as good as mine," the Hatter retorted, "you wouldn't speak of wasting it. Time is a person." "I don't understand what you mean," said Alice. "Of course, you don't!" the Hatter exclaimed, tossing his head dismissively. "I bet you've never even had a conversation with Time!" "Perhaps not," Alice responded cautiously, "but I know I have to keep time when I practice music." "Ah! That clarifies it," said the Hatter. "He can't stand being beaten. Now, if you just stayed on good terms with him, he'd adjust the clock almost any way you wanted. For instance, imagine it was nine in the morning, lesson time: you'd only need to whisper a hint to Time, and instantly, the clock would jump! Half-past one, time for dinner!" (The March Hare whispered to himself, "I only wish it were.") "That would indeed be wonderful," Alice said thoughtfully, "but then--I wouldn't be hungry for it, you know." "Not right away, maybe," the Hatter conceded, "but you could leave it at half-past one for as long as you wished." "Is that how you manage things?" Alice inquired. The Hatter shook his head sadly. "Not us!" he replied. "We fell out last March--just before he lost his mind, you see--" (gesturing at the March Hare with his tea spoon) "--it was during the big concert hosted by the Queen of Hearts, and I was supposed to sing 'Twinkle, twinkle, little bat! How I wonder what you're at!' You might know the tune?" "I've heard something similar," Alice acknowledged. "It continues, you know," the Hatter went on, "like this:-- 'Up above the world you fly, Like a tea-tray in the sky. Twinkle, twinkle--'" At this point, the Dormouse stirred and began singing "Twinkle, twinkle, twinkle, twinkle--" in its sleep, going on for so long that they had to pinch it to make it stop. "Well, I'd barely finished the first verse," the Hatter recounted, "when the Queen leaped up and screamed, 'He's murdering the time! Off with his head!'" "How incredibly cruel!" Alice exclaimed. "And ever since then," the Hatter continued in a melancholy voice, "Time refuses to do anything I ask! It's always six o'clock now." A sudden thought occurred to Alice. "Is that why there are so many tea-things laid out here?" she asked. "Yes, precisely," said the Hatter with a sigh. "It's perpetually tea-time, and we never have a moment to wash the dishes in between." "Then I assume you just move around the table?" Alice proposed. "Exactly," the Hatter confirmed, "as the items get used up."

‘Twinkle, twinkle, little bat!

You’ve probably heard the song?”
“I’ve heard something similar,” Alice responded.
The Hatter continued, “It goes like this:
‘Up above the world you fly,
Like a tea-tray in the sky.
Twinkle, twinkle—’”
At that point, the Dormouse stirred and began singing in its sleep, “Twinkle, twinkle, twinkle, twinkle—”, and kept going until they had to pinch it to get it to stop.

Alice suddenly understood. “Is that why there are so many cups and plates out here?” she asked.
“That’s exactly right,” sighed the Hatter. “It’s always tea-time, and we never have time to wash up in between.”
“So you just keep moving around the table?” Alice said.
“Precisely,” answered the Hatter. “We rotate as we use up the settings.”

events.title: The Dormouse's Story of the Treacle-Well Begins
detailed_summary: Alice inquires about what happens when they circle back to the start of the table.
The March Hare interrupts, changing the subject due to boredom and suggesting Alice tell a story.
Alice declines, feeling unprepared.
The March Hare and Hatter decide the Dormouse must tell a story and wake it by pinching.
The Dormouse, denying it was asleep, agrees to tell a story.
The Hatter urges it to be quick.
The Dormouse begins a story about three sisters (Elsie, Lacie, Tillie) living at the bottom of a well.
Alice interrupts, asking what they ate.
The Dormouse replies, after some thought, that they lived on treacle.
Alice gently objects that this would make them ill.
The Dormouse confirms they were indeed very ill.
Puzzled, Alice asks why they lived at the bottom of a well.
The March Hare interrupts again, earnestly offering Alice more tea.
Alice, offended, states she can't take *more* tea as she hasn't had any yet.
The Hatter corrects her, saying she means she can't take *less*, as taking more than nothing is easy.
Alice tells the Hatter his opinion wasn't requested.
The Hatter retorts, asking who is making personal remarks now.
Unsure how to respond, Alice takes some tea and bread-and-butter.
She repeats her question to the Dormouse about why the sisters lived in a well.
The Dormouse replies, after thinking, that it was a treacle-well.
Alice angrily starts to deny the existence of treacle-wells, but is shushed by the Hatter and March Hare.
The Dormouse sulkily suggests Alice finish the story herself if she can't be civil.
Alice humbly apologizes and asks the Dormouse to continue, conceding that perhaps one treacle-well exists.
The Dormouse expresses indignation at the suggestion there might be only one.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “But what happens when you come to the beginning again?” Alice ventured to ask.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “One, indeed!” said the Dormouse indignantly.

events.text_segment:
“But what happens when you come to the beginning again?” Alice ventured to ask.
“Suppose we change the subject,” the March Hare interrupted, yawning. “I’m getting tired of this. I vote the young lady tells us a story.”
“I’m afraid I don’t know one,” said Alice, rather alarmed at the proposal.
“Then the Dormouse shall!” they both cried. “Wake up, Dormouse!” And they pinched it on both sides at once.
The Dormouse slowly opened his eyes. “I wasn’t asleep,” he said in a hoarse, feeble voice: “I heard every word you fellows were saying.”
“Tell us a story!” said the March Hare.
“Yes, please do!” pleaded Alice.
“And be quick about it,” added the Hatter, “or you’ll be asleep again before it’s done.”
“Once upon a time there were three little sisters,” the Dormouse began in a great hurry; “and their names were Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie; and they lived at the bottom of a well—”
“What did they live on?” said Alice, who always took a great interest in questions of eating and drinking.
“They lived on treacle,” said the Dormouse, after thinking a minute or two.
“They couldn’t have done that, you know,” Alice gently remarked; “they’d have been ill.”
“So they were,” said the Dormouse; “very ill.”
Alice tried to fancy to herself what such an extraordinary ways of living would be like, but it puzzled her too much, so she went on: “But why did they live at the bottom of a well?”
“Take some more tea,” the March Hare said to Alice, very earnestly.
“I’ve had nothing yet,” Alice replied in an offended tone, “so I can’t take more.”
“You mean you can’t take less,” said the Hatter: “it’s very easy to take more than nothing.”
“Nobody asked your opinion,” said Alice.
“Who’s making personal remarks now?” the Hatter asked triumphantly.
Alice did not quite know what to say to this: so she helped herself to some tea and bread-and-butter, and then turned to the Dormouse, and repeated her question. “Why did they live at the bottom of a well?”
The Dormouse again took a minute or two to think about it, and then said, “It was a treacle-well.”
“There’s no such thing!” Alice was beginning very angrily, but the Hatter and the March Hare went “Sh! sh!” and the Dormouse sulkily remarked, “If you can’t be civil, you’d better finish the story for yourself.”
“No, please go on!” Alice said very humbly; “I won’t interrupt again. I dare say there may be one.”
“One, indeed!” said the Dormouse indignantly.

events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Alice, curious, asked, “But what happens when you reach the start again?” The March Hare, sleepy and uninterested, cut in. “Let’s talk about something else,” he yawned. “Why doesn’t the young lady tell us a story?” Alice was taken aback and replied, “I’m afraid I don’t know any stories.” “Then the Dormouse will have to!” both the Hare and the Hatter said, poking the Dormouse to wake him up. The Dormouse opened his eyes slowly and croaked, “I wasn’t asleep. I heard everything you said.” The March Hare insisted, “Tell us a story!” Alice joined in the request, and the Hatter warned, “Be quick, or you’ll nod off again before you finish.”

So, in a hurry, the Dormouse started: “Once upon a time there were three sisters—Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie—who lived at the bottom of a well.” Alice, always curious about food, asked, “What did they eat?” After thinking, the Dormouse replied, “They lived on treacle.” Alice pointed out, “But they couldn’t have only eaten treacle, they’d be sick.” “They were,” the Dormouse said, “very sick indeed.”

Alice tried to imagine such a strange life, but grew too confused. She asked, “But why did they live at the bottom of a well?” The March Hare told Alice to have more tea. Alice responded indignantly, “I haven’t had any yet, so I can’t have more.” The Hatter corrected her, saying, “You can always have more than nothing; it’s less you can’t take.” Alice shot back, “Nobody asked for your input.” The Hatter, feeling victorious, replied, “Who’s making personal comments now?” Unsure how to answer, Alice took some tea and bread-and-butter, then asked the Dormouse again why the sisters lived at the bottom of a well.

After thinking, the Dormouse replied, “It was a treacle-well.” Alice was about to argue that such a thing didn’t exist, but the Hatter and the Hare hushed her, and the Dormouse, grumpy, told her to finish the story herself if she couldn’t be polite. “Please, go on—I won’t interrupt anymore,” Alice said apologetically. “Maybe such a well does exist.” The Dormouse, offended, snorted, “One, indeed!”

events.title: The Nonsensical Story Continues, the Party Shifts, and Alice Departs
detailed_summary: The Dormouse agrees to continue the story about the three sisters learning to draw.
Alice, forgetting her promise not to interrupt, asks what they drew.
The Dormouse instantly replies, "Treacle."
The Hatter interrupts, wanting a clean cup and initiating a move one place along the table.
Everyone shifts: Dormouse follows Hatter, March Hare takes Dormouse's place, Alice unwillingly takes March Hare's (recently dirtied) place.
Only the Hatter benefits from the change.
Alice cautiously asks the Dormouse where the treacle was drawn from.
The Hatter interjects with a nonsensical analogy about drawing water from a water-well implying treacle can be drawn from a treacle-well, calling Alice stupid.
Alice ignores the Hatter and points out to the Dormouse that the sisters were *in* the well.
The Dormouse confirms this, saying they were "well in".
Confused, Alice lets the Dormouse continue without interruption.
The Dormouse, getting sleepy, resumes, stating the sisters drew things beginning with the letter M.
Alice asks why M.
The March Hare retorts, "Why not?".
Alice remains silent.
The Dormouse dozes off but is pinched awake by the Hatter.
It continues listing things starting with M: mouse-traps, moon, memory, muchness, asking if Alice has seen a drawing of muchness.
Alice, confused, starts to say she doesn't think so.
The Hatter rudely tells her she shouldn't talk then.
This final rudeness prompts Alice to leave the tea party in disgust.
The Dormouse falls asleep immediately, and the Hatter and March Hare ignore Alice's departure, instead attempting to put the Dormouse in the teapot.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: However, he consented to go on.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This piece of rudeness was more than Alice could bear: she got up in great disgust, and walked off; the Dormouse fell asleep instantly, and neither of the others took the least notice of her going, though she looked back once or twice, half hoping that they would call after her: the last time she saw them, they were trying to put the Dormouse into the teapot.

events.text_segment:
However, he consented to go on. “And so these three little sisters—they were learning to draw, you know—”
“What did they draw?” said Alice, quite forgetting her promise.
“Treacle,” said the Dormouse, without considering at all this time.
“I want a clean cup,” interrupted the Hatter: “let’s all move one place on.”
He moved on as he spoke, and the Dormouse followed him: the March Hare moved into the Dormouse’s place, and Alice rather unwillingly took the place of the March Hare. The Hatter was the only one who got any advantage from the change: and Alice was a good deal worse off than before, as the March Hare had just upset the milk-jug into his plate.
Alice did not wish to offend the Dormouse again, so she began very cautiously: “But I don’t understand. Where did they draw the treacle from?”
“You can draw water out of a water-well,” said the Hatter; “so I should think you could draw treacle out of a treacle-well—eh, stupid?”
“But they were in the well,” Alice said to the Dormouse, not choosing to notice this last remark.
“Of course they were,” said the Dormouse; “—well in.”
This answer so confused poor Alice, that she let the Dormouse go on for some time without interrupting it.
“They were learning to draw,” the Dormouse went on, yawning and rubbing its eyes, for it was getting very sleepy; “and they drew all manner of things—everything that begins with an M—”
“Why with an M?” said Alice.
“Why not?” said the March Hare.
Alice was silent.
The Dormouse had closed its eyes by this time, and was going off into a doze; but, on being pinched by the Hatter, it woke up again with a little shriek, and went on: “—that begins with an M, such as mouse-traps, and the moon, and memory, and muchness—you know you say things are “much of a muchness”—did you ever see such a thing as a drawing of a muchness?”
“Really, now you ask me,” said Alice, very much confused, “I don’t think—”
“Then you shouldn’t talk,” said the Hatter.
This piece of rudeness was more than Alice could bear: she got up in great disgust, and walked off; the Dormouse fell asleep instantly, and neither of the others took the least notice of her going, though she looked back once or twice, half hoping that they would call after her: the last time she saw them, they were trying to put the Dormouse into the teapot.

"So, there were these three young sisters who were taking drawing lessons, you see—" Alice, completely forgetting her earlier promise, asked, "What did they draw?" The Dormouse replied, "Treacle," this time without any hesitation or thought. "I need a clean cup," the Hatter interrupted, "let's all shift one seat over." As he spoke, he shifted over, followed by the Dormouse. The March Hare then occupied the Dormouse's vacated spot, while Alice reluctantly moved into the March Hare's seat. The Hatter was the sole beneficiary of this relocation, while Alice found herself significantly worse off, since the March Hare had just spilled the milk jug into his dish. Cautious not to upset the Dormouse again, Alice tentatively began, "But I don't quite get it. Where did they get the treacle to draw?" "You can extract water from a well," the Hatter stated, "so logically, you could get treacle from a treacle-well, wouldn't you think—you idiot?" "But they were *inside* the well," Alice said to the Dormouse, opting to ignore the Hatter's final comment. "Naturally, they were," the Dormouse confirmed, "—well inside." This response left poor Alice utterly bewildered, causing her to let the Dormouse continue its story for a while without interruption. "They were having drawing lessons," the Dormouse resumed, yawning and rubbing its eyes, clearly getting very drowsy, "and they drew all sorts of things—anything starting with the letter M—" "Why only M?" Alice asked. "Why shouldn't they?" the March Hare retorted. Alice had no reply. By now, the Dormouse's eyes were shut, and it was drifting off to sleep. However, after the Hatter gave it a pinch, it awoke with a small cry and continued: "—things that start with M, like mouse-traps, the moon, memory, and 'muchness'—you know how people say things are 'much of a muchness'—have you ever encountered a drawing of 'muchness'?" "Honestly, now that you mention it," a very perplexed Alice began, "I don't believe—" "In that case, you ought to keep quiet," the Hatter stated. This final instance of rudeness was unbearable for Alice. She stood up in utter dismay and left. The Dormouse immediately fell asleep, and neither the Hatter nor the March Hare paid any attention to her departure, even though she glanced back once or twice, partly wishing they would call her back. When she last saw them, they were attempting to stuff the Dormouse into the teapot.

"I need a clean cup," the Hatter cut in. "Let's each move one spot over."
As he spoke, he shifted places and the Dormouse followed. The March Hare took the Dormouse's seat, and Alice, not very enthusiastically, took the spot just vacated by the March Hare. Only the Hatter benefited from the switch: Alice found herself in a worse position, since the March Hare had just spilled the milk-jug all over his plate.

events.title: Alice Leaves the Tea Party and Discovers a Door in a Tree
detailed_summary: Walking through the woods, Alice resolves never to return to the tea party, calling it the stupidest she ever attended.
She notices a tree with a door leading directly into it.
Finding it curious, but accepting the general strangeness of the day, she decides to enter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “At any rate I’ll never go there again!” said Alice as she picked her way through the wood.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And in she went.

events.text_segment:
“At any rate I’ll never go there again!” said Alice as she picked her way through the wood. “It’s the stupidest tea-party I ever was at in all my life!”
Just as she said this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door leading right into it. “That’s very curious!” she thought. “But everything’s curious today. I think I may as well go in at once.” And in she went.

Just after saying this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door leading directly into it. “How peculiar!” she thought to herself. “But then again, everything is peculiar today. I think I might as well just go right in.” And so, she went inside.

As she spoke, she saw that a tree nearby had a door built into it. "How strange!" she remarked to herself. "But then, today has been full of oddities. I suppose I might as well go in right away." With that, she stepped inside.

events.title: Alice Returns to the Hall and Finally Enters the Garden
detailed_summary: Alice finds herself back in the familiar long hall near the glass table.
Confident she can manage better this time, she takes the golden key.
She unlocks the small door leading to the garden.
Using the piece of mushroom she saved, she adjusts her height until she is about twelve inches tall.
She walks through the little passage.
Finally, Alice successfully enters the beautiful garden she had longed to reach.

Then she went to work nibbling at the mushroom (she had kept a piece of it in her pocket) till she was about a foot high: then she walked down the little passage: and then—she found herself at last in the beautiful garden, among the bright flower-beds and the cool fountains.

events.title: Gardeners Painting Roses
detailed_summary: Alice observed three gardeners painting white roses red on a large rose tree near the garden entrance.
She overheard them arguing, with Five blaming Seven for jogging his elbow and splashing paint.
Seven accused Five of blaming others, and Five retorted that the Queen wanted Seven beheaded for bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.
Seven started to protest the injustice but stopped abruptly upon noticing Alice watching.
All three gardeners bowed low to Alice.
Alice timidly asked why they were painting the roses.
Two explained, prompted by the silence of Five and Seven, that they had mistakenly planted a white rose tree instead of a red one.
He elaborated that they feared the Queen would have them all beheaded if she discovered the mistake.
They were hastily trying to paint the roses red before the Queen's arrival.
Suddenly, Five shouted a warning that the Queen was coming, and the three gardeners immediately prostrated themselves on the ground.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily painting them red.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a sound of many footsteps, and Alice looked round, eager to see the Queen.

events.text_segment:
A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily painting them red. Alice thought this a very curious thing, and she went nearer to watch them, and just as she came up to them she heard one of them say, “Look out now, Five! Don’t go splashing paint over me like that!”
“I couldn’t help it,” said Five, in a sulky tone; “Seven jogged my elbow.”
On which Seven looked up and said, “That’s right, Five! Always lay the blame on others!”
“You’d better not talk!” said Five. “I heard the Queen say only yesterday you deserved to be beheaded!”
“What for?” said the one who had spoken first.
“That’s none of your business, Two!” said Seven.
“Yes, it is his business!” said Five, “and I’ll tell him—it was for bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.”
Seven flung down his brush, and had just begun “Well, of all the unjust things—” when his eye chanced to fall upon Alice, as she stood watching them, and he checked himself suddenly: the others looked round also, and all of them bowed low.
“Would you tell me,” said Alice, a little timidly, “why you are painting those roses?”
Five and Seven said nothing, but looked at Two. Two began in a low voice, “Why the fact is, you see, Miss, this here ought to have been a red rose-tree, and we put a white one in by mistake; and if the Queen was to find it out, we should all have our heads cut off, you know. So you see, Miss, we’re doing our best, afore she comes, to—” At this moment Five, who had been anxiously looking across the garden, called out “The Queen! The Queen!” and the three gardeners instantly threw themselves flat upon their faces. There was a sound of many footsteps, and Alice looked round, eager to see the Queen.

Five replied crossly that he couldn't help it because Seven had bumped his arm. Seven looked up and retorted, 'Typical, Five! Always blaming someone else!' Five told Seven not to talk, claiming he had heard the Queen say the day before that Seven deserved execution. The gardener who had spoken first asked why. Seven told him, Two, it wasn't his concern. Five insisted it was Two's concern and explained the reason: Seven had brought the cook tulip roots instead of onions. Seven threw down his brush and started complaining about the unfairness of it all, but then noticed Alice watching him. He stopped abruptly. The others also turned, and they all bowed deeply. Alice, feeling a bit nervous, asked why they were painting the roses. Five and Seven stayed quiet, looking at Two. Two explained in a low voice that the tree was supposed to be red, but they had accidentally planted a white one. He added that if the Queen found out, they would all lose their heads. So, he said, they were doing their best to fix it before she arrived... Just then, Five, who had been nervously scanning the garden, shouted, 'The Queen! The Queen!' The three gardeners immediately dropped flat onto their faces. The sound of many footsteps grew louder, and Alice looked around eagerly to see the Queen.

Don’t splash paint on me!” Five replied with annoyance, “I couldn’t help it; Seven bumped my elbow.” Seven, hearing this, retorted, “Of course, Five, you’re always blaming someone else!” Five snapped back, “You shouldn’t talk! Yesterday, I heard the Queen say you deserved to be beheaded!” The first gardener asked, “Why?” Seven replied sharply, “That’s none of your concern, Two!” but Five insisted it was and explained, “It was for giving the cook tulip roots instead of onions.” At that moment, Seven angrily threw down his brush and started to protest but noticed Alice watching them and stopped. The other two noticed her as well, and all three gardeners bowed low. The Queen!” Immediately, all three gardeners lay flat on the ground. Alice heard many footsteps and turned around, eager to catch a glimpse of the Queen.

events.title: The Royal Procession Arrives
detailed_summary: A procession began, led by ten club-carrying soldiers shaped like playing cards.
Following them were ten courtiers adorned with diamonds, walking in pairs.
Next came ten royal children, decorated with hearts, skipping hand-in-hand in couples.
A group of guests, mainly Kings and Queens, followed, among whom Alice spotted the White Rabbit.
The White Rabbit appeared nervous, smiled at everything, and passed by Alice without recognizing her.
The Knave of Hearts followed, carrying the King's crown on a cushion.
Finally, the King and Queen of Hearts appeared at the end of the grand procession.
Alice considered lying face down like the gardeners but decided against it, reasoning that processions were meant to be seen.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like the three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the corners: next the ten courtiers; these were ornamented all over with diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So she stood still where she was, and waited.

events.text_segment:
First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like the three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the corners: next the ten courtiers; these were ornamented all over with diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did. After these came the royal children; there were ten of them, and the little dears came jumping merrily along hand in hand, in couples: they were all ornamented with hearts. Next came the guests, mostly Kings and Queens, and among them Alice recognised the White Rabbit: it was talking in a hurried nervous manner, smiling at everything that was said, and went by without noticing her. Then followed the Knave of Hearts, carrying the King’s crown on a crimson velvet cushion; and, last of all this grand procession, came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS.
Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face like the three gardeners, but she could not remember ever having heard of such a rule at processions; “and besides, what would be the use of a procession,” thought she, “if people had all to lie down upon their faces, so that they couldn’t see it?” So she stood still where she was, and waited.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: The procession began with ten soldiers holding clubs. Like the gardeners before them, they were flat and rectangular, with limbs located at their corners. Following them were ten courtiers, who were adorned with diamonds and marched in pairs, just like the soldiers. Next came the ten royal children, who were decorated with hearts and skipped joyfully hand-in-hand in pairs. After the children, the guests appeared, primarily consisting of Kings and Queens. Among them, Alice spotted the White Rabbit, who was speaking quickly and nervously, smiling at every remark, and passed by without noticing her. The Knave of Hearts came after the guests, carrying the King's crown on a red velvet cushion. The impressive parade concluded with the arrival of THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS themselves. Alice wasn't sure if she should prostrate herself face-down, as the three gardeners had done, but she couldn't recall ever hearing such a rule for processions. She mused, "What purpose would a procession serve if everyone had to lie down and couldn't see it?" Consequently, she remained standing in her spot and waited.

They joyfully skipped along in pairs, holding hands, and each was adorned with hearts. Following the children were the guests, mostly kings and queens, in whose company Alice spotted the White Rabbit. He was talking quickly and nervously, smiling at everyone, but walked past Alice without noticing her. Behind them came the Knave of Hearts, who carried the King’s crown on a cushion of red velvet. Finally, at the end of this impressive parade, came the King and Queen of Hearts.

Alice wondered if she should lie face-down on the ground like the three gardeners did, but she couldn’t recall ever hearing of such a rule during processions. ‘Moreover, what would be the point of a procession,’ she thought, ‘if everyone had to lie on their faces and couldn’t see it?’ So, she decided to remain standing and wait.

events.title: Alice Confronts the Queen
detailed_summary: The entire procession halted upon reaching Alice.
The Queen sternly asked the Knave of Hearts to identify Alice, but the Knave only bowed and smiled.
The Queen impatiently called the Knave an idiot and turned to Alice, demanding her name.
Alice politely introduced herself as Alice but privately reminded herself that they were merely a pack of cards and she shouldn't be afraid.
The Queen then pointed to the prostrate gardeners and asked Alice who they were, unable to identify them due to their face-down position and card-like appearance.
Alice, surprising herself with her boldness, replied that it was none of her business.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked at her, and the Queen said severely “Who is this?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It’s no business of mine.”

events.text_segment:
When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked at her, and the Queen said severely “Who is this?” She said it to the Knave of Hearts, who only bowed and smiled in reply.
“Idiot!” said the Queen, tossing her head impatiently; and, turning to Alice, she went on, “What’s your name, child?”
“My name is Alice, so please your Majesty,” said Alice very politely; but she added, to herself, “Why, they’re only a pack of cards, after all. I needn’t be afraid of them!”
“And who are these?” said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who were lying round the rose-tree; for, you see, as they were lying on their faces, and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the pack, she could not tell whether they were gardeners, or soldiers, or courtiers, or three of her own children.
“How should I know?” said Alice, surprised at her own courage. “It’s no business of mine.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: When the group reached Alice, they all stopped and stared at her. The Queen sternly addressed the Knave of Hearts, demanding, "Who is this?" The Knave's only response was a bow and a smile. The Queen impatiently shook her head and exclaimed, "Idiot!" before turning to Alice and asking, "What is your name, child?" Alice replied very politely, "My name is Alice, if it pleases your Majesty." However, she added silently to herself, "They are, after all, just a deck of cards. I don't need to be afraid of them!" Pointing to the three gardeners lying around the rose-tree, the Queen then asked, "And who are these people?" Since they were lying on their fronts and the pattern on their backs matched the rest of the pack, she couldn't tell if they were gardeners, soldiers, courtiers, or even three of her own children. "How am I supposed to know?" Alice responded, astonished by her own boldness. "That's not my concern."

"How am I supposed to know?" Alice replied, a little surprised by her own boldness. "That's not my concern."

events.title: Gardeners Saved, Croquet Invitation Issued
detailed_summary: The Queen became enraged at Alice's response and furiously ordered her execution.
Alice loudly and firmly dismissed the order as nonsense, which silenced the Queen.
The King gently intervened, reminding the Queen that Alice was only a child.
The Queen angrily turned away from the King and ordered the Knave to turn the gardeners over.
The Knave carefully flipped the gardeners using his foot.
The Queen commanded the gardeners to get up, and they immediately did, bowing profusely to everyone.
The Queen yelled at them to stop bowing as it made her dizzy.
Turning to the rose tree, she demanded to know what the gardeners had been doing.
Two humbly began to explain, kneeling, that they were trying to fix their mistake.
The Queen, having examined the roses, cut him off, declared "Off with their heads!", and the procession started moving again.
Three soldiers stayed behind to execute the gardeners, who ran to Alice for protection.
Alice declared they wouldn't be beheaded and hid them in a large, nearby flower-pot.
The soldiers searched briefly, failed to find the gardeners, and marched off after the procession.
The Queen shouted from a distance, asking if the gardeners' heads were off.
The soldiers shouted back that their heads were gone.
Satisfied, the Queen shouted back, asking if Alice could play croquet.
The soldiers looked expectantly at Alice, who confirmed she could play.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a moment like a wild beast, screamed “Off with her head! Off—”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Yes!” shouted Alice.

events.text_segment:
The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a moment like a wild beast, screamed “Off with her head! Off—”
“Nonsense!” said Alice, very loudly and decidedly, and the Queen was silent.
The King laid his hand upon her arm, and timidly said “Consider, my dear: she is only a child!”
The Queen turned angrily away from him, and said to the Knave “Turn them over!”
The Knave did so, very carefully, with one foot.
“Get up!” said the Queen, in a shrill, loud voice, and the three gardeners instantly jumped up, and began bowing to the King, the Queen, the royal children, and everybody else.
“Leave off that!” screamed the Queen. “You make me giddy.” And then, turning to the rose-tree, she went on, “What have you been doing here?”
“May it please your Majesty,” said Two, in a very humble tone, going down on one knee as he spoke, “we were trying—”
“I see!” said the Queen, who had meanwhile been examining the roses. “Off with their heads!” and the procession moved on, three of the soldiers remaining behind to execute the unfortunate gardeners, who ran to Alice for protection.
“You shan’t be beheaded!” said Alice, and she put them into a large flower-pot that stood near. The three soldiers wandered about for a minute or two, looking for them, and then quietly marched off after the others.
“Are their heads off?” shouted the Queen.
“Their heads are gone, if it please your Majesty!” the soldiers shouted in reply.
“That’s right!” shouted the Queen. “Can you play croquet?”
The soldiers were silent, and looked at Alice, as the question was evidently meant for her.
“Yes!” shouted Alice.

"Stand up!" the Queen commanded in a high-pitched, loud voice, and the three gardeners immediately stood up and started bowing to the King, the Queen, the royal family members, and everyone else present. "If it pleases your Majesty," said Two in a very humble tone, kneeling as he spoke, "we were attempting—" "I understand!" the Queen exclaimed, having inspected the roses. "Cut off their heads!"
