The King questioned her further, emphasizing if she really knew nothing at all, and Alice confirmed. The King declared this fact significant, addressing the jury as they began to write it down, but the White Rabbit respectfully corrected him, suggesting he meant 'insignificant' instead, while making faces behind his back. The King quickly agreed, clarifying out loud that he did mean 'unimportant,' and then muttered to himself, alternating between 'important' and 'unimportant' as if deciding which sounded better. Some jurors wrote 'important,' others wrote 'unimportant,' which Alice, standing nearby, could see, but she thought it did not matter anyway.

events.title: Rule Forty-Two and Alice's Logical Defiance
detailed_summary: The King, after writing in his notebook, shouts for silence and reads "Rule Forty-two": anyone over a mile high must leave court.
All eyes turn to Alice.
Alice protests that she is not a mile high.
The King contradicts her, and the Queen adds that Alice is nearly two miles high.
Alice firmly states she won't leave, asserting the rule is irregular and just invented by the King.
The King claims it's the oldest rule in the book.
Alice retorts that, if true, it should logically be Rule Number One.
Visibly flustered, the King turns pale, snaps his notebook shut, and nervously tells the jury to consider their verdict.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, cackled out “Silence!” and read out from his book, “Rule Forty-two. All persons more than a mile high to leave the court.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily. “Consider your verdict,” he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.

events.text_segment:
At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, cackled out “Silence!” and read out from his book, “Rule Forty-two. All persons more than a mile high to leave the court.”
Everybody looked at Alice.
“I’m not a mile high,” said Alice.
“You are,” said the King.
“Nearly two miles high,” added the Queen.
“Well, I shan’t go, at any rate,” said Alice: “besides, that’s not a regular rule: you invented it just now.”
“It’s the oldest rule in the book,” said the King.
“Then it ought to be Number One,” said Alice.
The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily. “Consider your verdict,” he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: At this point, the King, who had been preoccupied with writing in his notebook for some time, suddenly crowed "Silence!" He then read aloud from his book, "Rule Forty-two. Anyone exceeding a height of one mile must exit the court." Everyone present directed their gaze towards Alice. "I am not one mile tall," Alice stated. "Indeed, you are," the King insisted. The Queen added, "Almost two miles tall." Alice declared, "Well, I certainly won't be leaving regardless; besides, that's not an established rule, you just created it." The King responded, "It is the most ancient rule in the book." Alice countered, "In that case, it should logically be Rule Number One." The King went pale, quickly closed his notebook, and addressed the jury in a hushed, shaky voice, saying, "Deliberate on your verdict."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: At that point, the King—who had been busily jotting notes—suddenly called out, "Silence!" and announced, "Rule Forty-two: Anyone taller than a mile must leave the court." Everyone stared at Alice. "I’m not a mile high," Alice protested. "Yes, you are," the King insisted. "Almost two miles high," the Queen chimed in. "Well, I’m not leaving no matter what," Alice replied. "Anyway, that’s not a real rule; you just made it up." "It’s actually the oldest rule in the book," asserted the King. "Then it should be Rule Number One," Alice pointed out. The King turned pale, quickly closed his notebook, and nervously told the jury, "Consider your verdict."

events.title: Mysterious Unsigned Verses Presented as Evidence
detailed_summary: The White Rabbit hastily interrupts, announcing new evidence in the form of a recently found paper.
The Queen inquires about its contents.
The Rabbit explains it appears to be a letter from the prisoner to someone, but he hasn't opened it yet.
The King speculates it must be addressed to someone, unless, unusually, it was written to nobody.
A juryman asks who it is addressed to.
The Rabbit reveals it has no address and nothing written on the outside.
He unfolds the paper and clarifies it's not a letter but a set of verses.
Another juryman asks if the verses are in the prisoner's handwriting.
The Rabbit replies that they are not, which he finds very peculiar, baffling the jury.
The King suggests the prisoner must have imitated someone else's handwriting, which seems to satisfy the jury.
The Knave speaks up, denying he wrote it and stating they cannot prove he did, as there is no signature.
The King illogically argues that not signing makes matters worse, implying mischievous intent, a statement met with applause as his first clever remark.
The Queen declares the Knave's guilt proven by this.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “There’s more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,” said the White Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; “this paper has just been picked up.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “That proves his guilt,” said the Queen.

events.text_segment:
“There’s more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,” said the White Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; “this paper has just been picked up.”
“What’s in it?” said the Queen.
“I haven’t opened it yet,” said the White Rabbit, “but it seems to be a letter, written by the prisoner to—to somebody.”
“It must have been that,” said the King, “unless it was written to nobody, which isn’t usual, you know.”
“Who is it directed to?” said one of the jurymen.
“It isn’t directed at all,” said the White Rabbit; “in fact, there’s nothing written on the outside.” He unfolded the paper as he spoke, and added “It isn’t a letter, after all: it’s a set of verses.”
“Are they in the prisoner’s handwriting?” asked another of the jurymen.
“No, they’re not,” said the White Rabbit, “and that’s the queerest thing about it.” (The jury all looked puzzled.)
“He must have imitated somebody else’s hand,” said the King. (The jury all brightened up again.)
“Please your Majesty,” said the Knave, “I didn’t write it, and they can’t prove I did: there’s no name signed at the end.”
“If you didn’t sign it,” said the King, “that only makes the matter worse. You must have meant some mischief, or else you’d have signed your name like an honest man.”
There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really clever thing the King had said that day.
“That proves his guilt,” said the Queen.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Jumping up in a great rush, the White Rabbit told the King and Queen that more evidence was still to come and that this paper had just been discovered. The Queen asked what it contained. The White Rabbit replied that he hadn't opened it yet but believed it was a letter from the prisoner to someone. The King commented that it must be, unless it was written to nobody, which is uncommon. One of the jurymen asked who it was addressed to. The White Rabbit stated it wasn't addressed to anyone; in fact, there was nothing written on the outside. As he opened the paper, he corrected himself, saying it wasn't a letter after all, but a poem. Another juryman inquired if the verses were in the prisoner's handwriting. The White Rabbit said they were not, adding that this was the strangest part, which caused the jury to look confused. The King suggested the prisoner must have copied someone else's hand, which brightened up the jury. The Knave then spoke, pleading with the King and Queen that he didn't write it and they couldn't prove he did because it lacked a signature at the end. The King countered that not signing it only made his situation worse, implying he must have intended mischief, or he would have signed his name openly like an honest man. This statement received general applause, considered the King's most intelligent remark that day. The Queen then declared that this point proved his guilt.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"There's still more evidence, Your Majesty," exclaimed the White Rabbit, leaping up hurriedly. "This paper was just found." 
"What does it contain?" asked the Queen. 
"I haven't looked yet," replied the White Rabbit, "but it looks like a letter from the prisoner to someone." 
"That makes sense," said the King, "unless it was written to no one, which would be odd." 
"Who is it addressed to?" a juryman inquired. 
"It has no address at all," answered the White Rabbit. "Actually, nothing is written on the outside." He opened the paper as he spoke and continued, "It's not a letter after all—it's a poem." 
"Is it written in the prisoner's handwriting?" another juryman questioned. 
"No, it isn't," said the White Rabbit, "and that's the strangest part." (The jury looked very confused.) 
"He must have copied someone else's writing," the King suggested. (The jury's faces brightened again.)
"Your Majesty," protested the Knave, "I didn't write it, and they can't prove I did; there is no signature at the end."
"If you didn't sign it," said the King, "that only makes things worse. You must have had some bad intention, or you would have signed your name like an honest person."
Everyone applauded this comment as it was the first truly smart thing the King had said that day.
"That shows he's guilty," declared the Queen.

events.title: Nonsensical Poem Reading and Absurd Interpretation
detailed_summary: Alice interjects, stating the verses prove nothing as their meaning is unknown.
The King instructs the White Rabbit to read the verses.
The Rabbit puts on spectacles and asks where to start.
The King gravely tells him to begin at the beginning, continue to the end, and then stop.
The White Rabbit reads a nonsensical poem involving pronouns, swimming ability, gifts, and secrets.
The King declares the poem the most important evidence yet and prepares to instruct the jury.
Alice, now larger and bolder, interrupts, offering money to anyone who can explain the poem, stating her belief that it lacks any meaning.
The jury members write down Alice's disbelief but don't try to interpret the verses.
The King initially suggests that meaninglessness simplifies things, but then reconsiders, attempting to decipher the poem.
He connects a line about not swimming to the Knave, who confirms his inability to swim.
He links lines about giving items to the tarts, declaring the connection obvious when Alice points out a line about items being returned.
He tries to link a line about a 'fit' to the Queen, who reacts furiously, denies having fits, and throws an inkstand at the Lizard.
The Lizard begins writing with the spilled ink.
The King concludes the words about fits don't suit the Queen, makes a pun on 'fit', and is offended by the silence before everyone laughs.
He repeats his instruction for the jury to consider their verdict.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “It proves nothing of the sort!” said Alice. “Why, you don’t even know what they’re about!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Let the jury consider their verdict,” the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.

events.text_segment:
“It proves nothing of the sort!” said Alice. “Why, you don’t even know what they’re about!”
“Read them,” said the King.
The White Rabbit put on his spectacles. “Where shall I begin, please your Majesty?” he asked.
“Begin at the beginning,” the King said gravely, “and go on till you come to the end: then stop.”
These were the verses the White Rabbit read:—
“They told me you had been to her,
    And mentioned me to him:
She gave me a good character,
    But said I could not swim.

He sent them word I had not gone
    (We know it to be true):
If she should push the matter on,
    What would become of you?

I gave her one, they gave him two,
    You gave us three or more;
They all returned from him to you,
    Though they were mine before.

If I or she should chance to be
    Involved in this affair,
He trusts to you to set them free,
    Exactly as we were.

My notion was that you had been
    (Before she had this fit)
An obstacle that came between
    Him, and ourselves, and it.

Don’t let him know she liked them best,
    For this must ever be
A secret, kept from all the rest,
    Between yourself and me.”
“That’s the most important piece of evidence we’ve heard yet,” said the King, rubbing his hands; “so now let the jury—”
“If any one of them can explain it,” said Alice, (she had grown so large in the last few minutes that she wasn’t a bit afraid of interrupting him,) “I’ll give him sixpence. I don’t believe there’s an atom of meaning in it.”
The jury all wrote down on their slates, “She doesn’t believe there’s an atom of meaning in it,” but none of them attempted to explain the paper.
“If there’s no meaning in it,” said the King, “that saves a world of trouble, you know, as we needn’t try to find any. And yet I don’t know,” he went on, spreading out the verses on his knee, and looking at them with one eye; “I seem to see some meaning in them, after all. “—said I could not swim—” you can’t swim, can you?” he added, turning to the Knave.
The Knave shook his head sadly. “Do I look like it?” he said. (Which he certainly did not, being made entirely of cardboard.)
“All right, so far,” said the King, and he went on muttering over the verses to himself: “‘We know it to be true—’ that’s the jury, of course—‘I gave her one, they gave him two—’ why, that must be what he did with the tarts, you know—”
“But, it goes on ‘they all returned from him to you,’” said Alice.
“Why, there they are!” said the King triumphantly, pointing to the tarts on the table. “Nothing can be clearer than that. Then again—‘before she had this fit—’ you never had fits, my dear, I think?” he said to the Queen.
“Never!” said the Queen furiously, throwing an inkstand at the Lizard as she spoke. (The unfortunate little Bill had left off writing on his slate with one finger, as he found it made no mark; but he now hastily began again, using the ink, that was trickling down his face, as long as it lasted.)
“Then the words don’t fit you,” said the King, looking round the court with a smile. There was a dead silence.
“It’s a pun!” the King added in an offended tone, and everybody laughed, “Let the jury consider their verdict,” the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: “That doesn’t prove anything at all!” Alice exclaimed. “Why, you don’t even understand what the topic is!” The King simply replied, “Read them.” The White Rabbit carefully placed his spectacles on. “Where should I start, if it pleases your Majesty?” he inquired. The King responded gravely, “Begin at the very start, and continue until you get to the finish: then stop.” These were the lines that the White Rabbit proceeded to read: [The poem is read aloud, consisting of six four-line stanzas with an ABCB rhyme scheme, describing interactions and transfers between unspecified 'you', 'her', 'him', and 'they', involving concepts like character, swimming ability, messages, items given and returned, potential involvement in an 'affair', an 'obstacle', and a 'secret'.] The King, rubbing his hands together, declared, “That is the most significant piece of evidence we’ve heard yet; so now let the jury—” Alice, who had grown considerably larger in the preceding minutes and was no longer afraid to interrupt him, said, “If anyone among them can explain it, I’ll give them sixpence. I am utterly convinced there isn’t the slightest bit of sense in it.” The jury members all jotted down on their slates, “She does not believe there is the slightest bit of sense in it,” but none attempted to clarify the document. “If there’s no sense in it,” the King commented, “that eliminates a world of difficulty, as you know, since we don’t need to attempt to find any. And yet I’m not entirely sure,” he continued, spreading the verses across his knee and inspecting them with one eye; “I seem to detect some sense in them after all. ‘—said I could not swim—’ You can’t swim, can you?” he added, turning to the Knave. The Knave sadly shook his head. “Do I look like I could?” he replied. (Which he certainly did not, being constructed entirely from cardboard.) “Alright, that makes sense so far,” the King said, going on to murmur over the verses to himself: “‘We know it to be true—’ that obviously refers to the jury—‘I gave her one, they gave him two—’ why, that must be what he did with the tarts, you know—” “But, it continues ‘they all returned from him to you,’” Alice pointed out. “Why, there they are!” the King exclaimed victoriously, pointing to the tarts on the table. “Nothing could be clearer than that. Then again—‘before she had this fit—’ You’ve never experienced fits, my dear, have you?” he asked the Queen. “Never!” the Queen screeched furiously, flinging an inkstand at the Lizard as she spoke. (The unfortunate little Bill had stopped writing on his slate with just one finger because it produced no mark; but he now quickly resumed, utilizing the ink that was dripping down his face, for as long as it lasted.) “Then the words don’t suit you,” the King said, smiling around the court. There was a profound silence. “It’s a joke! A play on words!” the King added in an offended tone, and everyone burst into laughter. “Let the jury deliberate on their verdict,” the King instructed, approximately the twentieth time that day.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
"That doesn't prove anything!" Alice protested. "You don't even understand what they're talking about!" 

"Read what it says," ordered the King.

The White Rabbit put on his glasses. "Where do I start, Your Majesty?" he asked.

"Start at the beginning," replied the King seriously, "and keep going until you reach the end, then stop."

The White Rabbit then read these lines:

"They said you visited her,
  And spoke of me to him;
She said nice things about me,
  But mentioned I couldn't swim.

He sent a reply saying I hadn't gone
  (Which we know is true):
If she pursues this matter,
  What will become of you?

I gave her one, they gave him two,
  You gave us three or more;
They were all returned from him to you,
  Though they were mine before.

If I or she gets caught up
  In this whole affair,
He trusts you to set things right,
  And put things as they were.

I thought that you had been
  (Before she had her spell)
Someone who stood between
  Him, and us, as well.

Don't let him know she liked them best,
  It must always be
A secret kept from everyone,
  Except just you and me."

"That's the most significant evidence we've heard," the King said, rubbing his hands. "Now, let's let the jury—"

"If anyone can make sense of that," Alice interrupted (she had grown so big she wasn't afraid of speaking up anymore), "I'll give them sixpence. I don't think there's any meaning to it at all."

The jurors all wrote, "She doesn't think there's any meaning to it," on their slates, but none tried to explain what it meant.

"If it has no meaning," said the King, "that makes things easier; we don't have to look for one. Yet..." He looked over the poem with one eye. "I feel like I can find some meaning in it. 'said I could not swim'—you can't swim, can you?" he asked the Knave.

The Knave shook his head. "Do I look like I can?" he replied sadly (and he certainly didn't—being made of cardboard).

"Good so far," said the King, reviewing the verses. "'We know it to be true'—that's probably the jury. 'I gave her one, they gave him two'—that must be about the tarts."

"But then it says 'they all returned from him to you,'" Alice pointed out.

"There you go!" the King exclaimed, gesturing at the tarts on the table. "That's obvious! Now—'before she had this fit'—you've never had fits, have you, my dear?" he asked the Queen.

"Never!" shouted the Queen, throwing an inkstand at the Lizard. (Poor Bill had stopped writing with his finger since it made no marks, but now desperately started writing in ink that was running down his face.)

"Then it doesn't apply to you," the King said, smiling at the court. A still silence followed.

"It's a pun!" the King said defensively, causing everyone to laugh. "Let the jury decide their verdict," he declared, for what seemed like the twentieth time that day.

events.title: Sentence Before Verdict and Alice's Final Rebellion
detailed_summary: The Queen interrupts the King's call for a verdict, demanding the sentence be given first.
Alice loudly protests this idea as illogical nonsense.
The Queen, turning purple with anger, orders Alice to be silent.
Alice defiantly refuses.
The Queen shrieks for Alice's execution.
Nobody in the court makes a move to carry out the order.
Alice, having reached her full height, dismisses the Queen and the entire court.
She declares that she doesn't care about them because they are nothing more than a pack of cards.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “No, no!” said the Queen. “Sentence first—verdict afterwards.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “You’re nothing but a pack of cards!”

events.text_segment:
“No, no!” said the Queen. “Sentence first—verdict afterwards.”
“Stuff and nonsense!” said Alice loudly. “The idea of having the sentence first!”
“Hold your tongue!” said the Queen, turning purple.
“I won’t!” said Alice.
“Off with her head!” the Queen shouted at the top of her voice. Nobody moved.
“Who cares for you?” said Alice, (she had grown to her full size by this time.) “You’re nothing but a pack of cards!”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: “Absolutely not!” insisted the Queen. “The sentence comes first—the judgment comes after.” “That's preposterous!” Alice exclaimed loudly. “The very idea of determining the punishment before the verdict!” “Silence!” commanded the Queen, her face turning a deep shade of purple. “I refuse to be silent!” Alice replied. “Behead her!” the Queen shrieked at the very top of her voice. Not a single person moved. “Why would anyone care about you?” asked Alice, who by this time had grown to her normal height. “You are nothing more than a deck of playing cards!”
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: "Not at all!" exclaimed the Queen. "The punishment comes first—the decision follows." "That's absurd!" Alice declared, raising her voice. "How can you give the punishment before the verdict?" "Be quiet!" the Queen barked, her face flushed with anger. "I will not!" replied Alice. Enraged, the Queen screamed, "Off with her head!" But no one did anything. "Who cares about you?" Alice said, now that she had grown to her full height. "You’re nothing but a bunch of playing cards!"

events.title: The Court Attacks and Alice Awakens
detailed_summary: In response to Alice's defiant declaration, the entire pack of cards rises into the air.
The cards fly down towards Alice, attacking her.
Alice lets out a small scream, a mix of fear and indignation, and attempts to push them away.
The chaotic scene abruptly dissolves.
Alice finds herself lying on a familiar riverbank.
Her head is resting in her sister's lap.
Her sister is gently brushing away dead leaves that have fallen onto Alice's face.
The sister gently tells Alice to wake up, remarking on how long she has slept.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At this the whole pack rose up into the air, and came flying down upon her: she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Wake up, Alice dear!” said her sister; “Why, what a long sleep you’ve had!”

events.text_segment:
At this the whole pack rose up into the air, and came flying down upon her: she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.
“Wake up, Alice dear!” said her sister; “Why, what a long sleep you’ve had!”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: At that moment, the complete collection of cards ascended into the air and descended upon her. She let out a small scream, part fear and part frustration, and attempted to push them away, only to realize she was lying on the riverbank, her head resting in her sister's lap. Her sister was gently removing some dead leaves that had drifted down from the trees onto her face. "Wake up, Alice, darling!" her sister called out; "My, you've had such a long nap!"
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
At that moment, the entire deck of cards soared into the air and swooped down towards her. Alice let out a small cry, partly afraid and partly annoyed, as she attempted to fend them off. Suddenly, she realized she was lying on the riverbank, her head resting in her sister’s lap, while her sister softly brushed away a few dead leaves that had drifted down onto Alice’s face from the trees above. 
“Wake up, Alice dear!” her sister said. “You’ve been asleep for such a long time!”

events.title: Alice Recounts Her Wonderland Dream to Her Sister
detailed_summary: Alice awakens and exclaims about the incredibly peculiar dream she has just had.
She proceeds to recount all the strange adventures from Wonderland to her sister, recalling them as best she can.
After Alice finishes her story, her sister gives her a kiss.
The sister confirms that it was indeed a strange dream.
She then tells Alice it's getting late and time to go inside for tea.
Alice gets up and runs off towards home.
While running, she reflects on what a truly wonderful dream it had been.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Oh, I’ve had such a curious dream!” said Alice, and she told her sister, as well as she could remember them, all these strange Adventures of hers that you have just been reading about; and when she had finished, her sister kissed her, and said, “It was a curious dream, dear, certainly: but now run in to your tea; it’s getting late.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So Alice got up and ran off, thinking while she ran, as well she might, what a wonderful dream it had been.

events.text_segment: “Oh, I’ve had such a curious dream!” said Alice, and she told her sister, as well as she could remember them, all these strange Adventures of hers that you have just been reading about; and when she had finished, her sister kissed her, and said, “It was a curious dream, dear, certainly: but now run in to your tea; it’s getting late.” So Alice got up and ran off, thinking while she ran, as well she might, what a wonderful dream it had been.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Upon waking, Alice exclaimed, “Oh, I experienced such an odd dream!” She then recounted to her sister, recalling as much as she could, all the bizarre escapades she had just lived through (the ones you, the reader, have just finished learning about). When she had finished sharing, her sister kissed her and commented, “Indeed, dear, it was certainly an unusual dream: but now you must go inside for your tea; it’s growing late.” Consequently, Alice got up and ran off, pondering as she went (as was quite reasonable), how marvelous the dream had been.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: "I've just had the most peculiar dream!" exclaimed Alice. She recounted to her sister, as best as she could recall, all the odd adventures she had just experienced and that you have just read. When she finished her story, her sister gave her a kiss and remarked, "It truly was a curious dream, my dear. But now go on in for your tea; it's getting late." With that, Alice got up and hurried away, reflecting as she went on how marvelous her dream had been.

events.title: The Sister Reflects and Begins Her Own Dream
characters: (in dream/memory: Alice, White Rabbit, Mouse, March Hare, Hatter, Dormouse, Queen, Duchess, Pig-baby, Gryphon, Lizard, Guinea-pigs, Mock Turtle)
detailed_summary: After Alice leaves, her sister remains seated just as she was.
She leans her head on her hand, watches the setting sun, and contemplates Alice's amazing adventures.
Gradually, the sister begins to enter a dream-like state herself.
She first dreams of Alice as a little girl, picturing her clasped hands and eager eyes, hearing her voice and seeing her characteristic head toss.
As she seems to listen, the real environment around her transforms, becoming populated by the strange figures from Alice's dream.
She senses the White Rabbit rushing through the grass, hears the Mouse splashing in the pool, the clatter of the Mad Tea Party, and the Queen's shrill orders for executions.
She recalls the pig-baby sneezing, crashing plates, the Gryphon's shriek, the Lizard's pencil squeaking, the suppressed guinea pigs, and the Mock Turtle's distant sobbing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But her sister sat still just as she left her, leaning her head on her hand, watching the setting sun, and thinking of little Alice and all her wonderful Adventures, till she too began dreaming after a fashion, and this was her dream:—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The long grass rustled at her feet as the White Rabbit hurried by—the frightened Mouse splashed his way through the neighbouring pool—she could hear the rattle of the teacups as the March Hare and his friends shared their never-ending meal, and the shrill voice of the Queen ordering off her unfortunate guests to execution—once more the pig-baby was sneezing on the Duchess’s knee, while plates and dishes crashed around it—once more the shriek of the Gryphon, the squeaking of the Lizard’s slate-pencil, and the choking of the suppressed guinea-pigs, filled the air, mixed up with the distant sobs of the miserable Mock Turtle.

events.text_segment:
But her sister sat still just as she left her, leaning her head on her hand, watching the setting sun, and thinking of little Alice and all her wonderful Adventures, till she too began dreaming after a fashion, and this was her dream:—
First, she dreamed of little Alice herself, and once again the tiny hands were clasped upon her knee, and the bright eager eyes were looking up into hers—she could hear the very tones of her voice, and see that queer little toss of her head to keep back the wandering hair that would always get into her eyes—and still as she listened, or seemed to listen, the whole place around her became alive with the strange creatures of her little sister’s dream.
The long grass rustled at her feet as the White Rabbit hurried by—the frightened Mouse splashed his way through the neighbouring pool—she could hear the rattle of the teacups as the March Hare and his friends shared their never-ending meal, and the shrill voice of the Queen ordering off her unfortunate guests to execution—once more the pig-baby was sneezing on the Duchess’s knee, while plates and dishes crashed around it—once more the shriek of the Gryphon, the squeaking of the Lizard’s slate-pencil, and the choking of the suppressed guinea-pigs, filled the air, mixed up with the distant sobs of the miserable Mock Turtle.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
However, her sister remained seated exactly where Alice had departed, her head resting on her hand, watching the setting sun and contemplating little Alice and all her remarkable experiences, until she too drifted into a dreamlike state, and this is what she dreamt:
Initially, she dreamt of little Alice herself; once more, the small hands were clasped on her knee, and the bright, eager eyes looked up into hers. She could distinctly hear the sound of her voice and see that peculiar little flick of her head, used to push back the stray hair that persistently fell into her eyes. And as she listened, or seemed to listen, the entire area around her came alive with the strange creatures from her younger sister’s fantasy.
The long grass rustled around her feet as the White Rabbit scampered past. The startled Mouse struggled his way through the nearby pond. She could hear the clatter of teacups as the March Hare and his companions shared their unending meal, and the piercing voice of the Queen ordering her unfortunate guests to be executed. Again, the pig-baby was sneezing on the Duchess's lap, while plates and dishes crashed around them. Once more, the Gryphon’s shriek, the Lizard’s slate-pencil squeaking, and the stifled gasps of the suppressed guinea-pigs filled the air, mingled with the faraway sobs of the sorrowful Mock Turtle.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
However, her sister remained seated just as Alice had left her, resting her head on her hand, gazing at the sun as it set, and pondering little Alice and all of her remarkable adventures, until she herself drifted into a sort of dream, and in her dream this is what occurred:

She first dreamed of Alice herself, with the small hands once again folded on her knee and the bright, curious eyes turned up to meet her own—she could practically hear the sound of Alice’s voice and see the familiar little toss of her head to move the stray hair out of her eyes that always threatened to fall in—and while she listened, or thought she was listening, the world around her seemed to fill with the fantastic beings from her little sister's adventures.

She could hear the grass swaying as the White Rabbit rushed past her feet, the frightened Mouse splashing in the nearby pool, the clatter of teacups as the March Hare and his friends held their endless tea party, and the high-pitched commands of the Queen sending away her ill-fated guests for execution—she saw again the pig-baby sneezing on the Duchess’s lap, plates and dishes smashing all around it—and once more, the Gryphon’s scream, the sound of the Lizard’s squeaking pencil, and the muted choking of the guinea-pigs filled the air, mingling with the far-off sobs of the sorrowful Mock Turtle.

events.title: The Sister Contrasts Dream and Reality, Envisioning Alice's Future
characters: (in imagination: Alice as adult, other children)
detailed_summary: The sister sits with closed eyes, feeling half-present in Wonderland.
She acknowledges that opening her eyes will return her to ordinary reality.

She contrasts the dream sounds with their real-world equivalents: wind in the grass for the Rabbit, rippling water for the Mouse, sheep-bells for teacups, a shepherd boy's voice for the Queen's shouts.
She knows the other strange noises (sneezing baby, Gryphon's shriek) would become the sounds of a busy farmyard, and the Mock Turtle's sobs would be replaced by distant cattle lowing.
Lastly, she envisions Alice in the future as a grown woman.
She imagines Alice retaining her childhood's simple, loving heart.
She pictures this future Alice gathering other children around her, enchanting them with strange stories, possibly including the long-ago dream of Wonderland.
She imagines Alice empathizing with the children's simple sorrows and finding joy in their simple pleasures, all while remembering her own childhood and those happy summer days.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So she sat on, with closed eyes, and half believed herself in Wonderland, though she knew she had but to open them again, and all would change to dull reality—the grass would be only rustling in the wind, and the pool rippling to the waving of the reeds—the rattling teacups would change to tinkling sheep-bells, and the Queen’s shrill cries to the voice of the shepherd boy—and the sneeze of the baby, the shriek of the Gryphon, and all the other queer noises, would change (she knew) to the confused clamour of the busy farm-yard—while the lowing of the cattle in the distance would take the place of the Mock Turtle’s heavy sobs.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Lastly, she pictured to herself how this same little sister of hers would, in the after-time, be herself a grown woman; and how she would keep, through all her riper years, the simple and loving heart of her childhood: and how she would gather about her other little children, and make their eyes bright and eager with many a strange tale, perhaps even with the dream of Wonderland of long ago: and how she would feel with all their simple sorrows, and find a pleasure in all their simple joys, remembering her own child-life, and the happy summer days.

events.text_segment:
So she sat on, with closed eyes, and half believed herself in Wonderland, though she knew she had but to open them again, and all would change to dull reality—the grass would be only rustling in the wind, and the pool rippling to the waving of the reeds—the rattling teacups would change to tinkling sheep-bells, and the Queen’s shrill cries to the voice of the shepherd boy—and the sneeze of the baby, the shriek of the Gryphon, and all the other queer noises, would change (she knew) to the confused clamour of the busy farm-yard—while the lowing of the cattle in the distance would take the place of the Mock Turtle’s heavy sobs.
Lastly, she pictured to herself how this same little sister of hers would, in the after-time, be herself a grown woman; and how she would keep, through all her riper years, the simple and loving heart of her childhood: and how she would gather about her other little children, and make their eyes bright and eager with many a strange tale, perhaps even with the dream of Wonderland of long ago: and how she would feel with all their simple sorrows, and find a pleasure in all their simple joys, remembering her own child-life, and the happy summer days.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: She remained sitting there with her eyes shut, partly believing she was in Wonderland, although she knew that simply opening them again would instantly change everything back to dull reality. The sounds would revert: the grass would only be rustling due to the wind, the pool would ripple solely from the reeds waving, the clanking teacups would turn into the gentle ringing of sheep-bells, the Queen's high-pitched screams would become the voice of the shepherd boy, and the baby's sneeze, the Gryphon's yell, and all the other peculiar noises would, she realised, transform into the chaotic din of a busy farmyard. The far-off mooing of cattle would substitute for the heavy sobs of the Mock Turtle. Lastly, she envisioned her little sister, the same one, growing into a woman in the future; she pictured how her sister would retain the simple, loving heart of her childhood throughout her mature years, and how she would attract other young children around her, making their eyes bright and eager with numerous strange stories, possibly even including the long-ago dream of Wonderland. She imagined how her sister would empathise with all their minor sorrows and find happiness in all their straightforward joys, remembering her own young life and the pleasant summer days.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
She continued to sit quietly with her eyes shut, almost convincing herself that she was truly in Wonderland. But she also knew that if she opened her eyes, the magical world would vanish and reality would return—she’d hear the normal sounds of grass moving in the breeze and the water in the pool stirred by the reeds. The loud clatter of teacups would become the light ringing of sheep-bells, the Queen’s high-pitched cries would be replaced by a shepherd boy’s voice, and the strange sounds—like the baby’s sneeze and the Gryphon’s cry—would turn into the mixed noises of a busy farmyard. In the distance, the deep sobs of the Mock Turtle would be replaced by the distant sound of cows lowing.

Then, she imagined her sister, in the future, grown up into a woman who would always keep the kindness and innocence of her childhood. She pictured her surrounded by children, entertaining them with wonderful stories—perhaps even the tale of Wonderland from her own youth. She envisioned her feeling empathy for their troubles and joy in their happiness, recalling her own childhood and the joyful days of summer.
